intro: Lepidium virginicum var. medium, commonly known as the common peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is an annual or biennial plant that typically grows in disturbed soils such as roadsides, fields, and waste areas. The plant has small, yellow flowers that appear in clusters, and its leaves are alternate, simple, and often hairy. It produces small, round seeds that are dispersed by wind, contributing to its widespread distribution. The species is part of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other economically important plants.
